title: BBC crew among those injured in explosion on Mount Etna
text:
BBC crew among those injured in explosion on Mount Etna 
Group pelted with boiling rocks and steam in incident triggered when lava came into contact with snow The eruption came from a crater on the southeastern side of Mount Etna. Photograph: GENIA/IPA/REX/Shutterstock View more sharing options Angela Giuffrida in Rome Thursday 16 March 2017 15.17 GMT 
A BBC crew was among ten people injured after a flow of lava triggered an explosion when it came into contact with snow on Mount Etna in Sicily on Thursday. 
Six of the ten were hospitalised, although their injuries are not reported to be serious. 
The BBC’s global science correspondent, Rebecca Morelle, was among the team on the volcano at the time of the eruption, which came from a crater on the southeastern side of the 3,000-metre peak. 
Describing the incident on Twitter, she said: “Lava flow mixed with steam – caused huge explosion – group pelted with boiling rocks and steam.” 
Morelle said the explosion caused head injuries, burns, cuts and bruises, adding that one volcanologist had told her it was the most dangerous incident he had experienced in a 30-year career. 
The incident was a “reminder of how dangerous & unpredictable volcanoes can be – everyone had a very lucky escape”, she wrote. Rebecca Morelle (@BBCMorelle) Running down a mountain pelted by rocks, dodging burning boulders and boiling steam - not an experience I ever ever want to repeat (8) 
It is the third time in less than three weeks that Europe’s most active volcano , which overlooks the city of Catania, has erupted, spewing lava almost 200 metres into the sky. 
The six injured were taken to hospitals in Catania and nearby Acireale. 
Mount Etna, a Unesco world heritage site since 2013, can burst into life several times year, although the last major eruption was in 1992. Topics
